i you know how to provide a tool and then also make the tool consumable so that we can build solutions that are
actually taking away some of the aspects of uh people's works that's not really driving their you know why they go to

when they're there okay so um i've been to um
talked to a lot of developers at go-to conferences and i got a great piece of advice which was if i knew more what
quantum computers could be used for i'd be more interested in learning about what they are and how they work so that's what we're doing here we're going
to start about you know what are demonstrations of business value and how can you actually use this productively
in applications to get results so um here are four examples and we're going to be diving into a couple of them in more detail but bbva is working with a
startup company multiverse computing on using quantum computers for portfolio optimization in the context of risk in
order to find you know the best investments that you can make while sort of for the given amount of risk that
you're willing to take and they're also looking at things like trading trajectories so big financial organizations are having to make large
movements in their positions and as they're making those moves they can only do it in big blocks people start to
realize the movement that they're taking and they start pre-trading and eating away at the the value of those
big moves in their position so they're looking at ways to optimize those trading trajectories over time
using this kind of technology save on foods is a midsize canadian grocer they they operate their grocery business over
three million square kilometers they have a lot of interesting and complex grocery challenges volkswagen is actually a really early
pioneer in quantum computing and looking at it for traffic flow optimization and their manufacturing floor i'll go into that in a little bit more detail and
minton ai is a startup company that operates all throughout the world
they are looking at not just protein folding but protein design so when they were looking at
developing uh protein therapeutics for covert 19 it was about choosing
amino acids in a sequence which would fold in a particular way so that they could bind and
to you know the covet virus in particular designed ways and each time they have that choice there's 20
possible combinations of amino acids they can choose at each site and then that compounds as they go on that all
has an effect on how the protein is going to fold so that design challenge is combinatorially complex that's a
feature you're going to see as we're talking through examples today problems which have big combinatorics and they
have actually worked out how to use our hybrid solver technologies so they can use quantum computers to design proteins
that have actually been synthesized and now taken to live virus testing so there are quantum design proteins that are out
in the world okay so i'm going to dive into these in a little bit more detail a couple of
them in particular volkswagen started their work with our i think a really valuable
mindset which was i want to work on something extremely practical something that everyone would understand you know it's not about geez i want to use
quantum computers to do machine learning to build space elevators to the moon they just wanted to do traffic flow
optimization and show that you could use this in in practical applications so um they actually launched what they uh sort
of position as the first real-time um uh commercial use of quantum computing
at um the web summit in lisbon they actually were optimizing the roots of the conference buses who were shuttling
the conference attendees around using android devices for the drivers with real live traffic information and
making remote calls to our quantum computer live as the buses were driving around and as complicated as it is to build
quantum computing systems uh supporting live real-time applications brings a whole bunch of other technical uh
infrastructure challenges which were really fun to face uh because for me you know it's not about the technology it's
about you know solving problems and helping people to solve problems uh so that was exciting but that lesson that
they learned from using that quantum computer to optimize traffic flow
caused them to understand okay well now we're understanding problem formulation how do we pose problems for the quantum computer that are sort of suitable for
quantum computing and take advantage of its capabilities versus what classical computers are good at and they started
looking internally to their own applications and one of which was they have
a long manufacturing floor which has a lot of elements to it and it's very difficult to optimize
and so they minimize the number of aspects of the manufacturing floor that can impact
the overall schedule because they have to plan it and take so much time to do that so some of the elements like
choosing paint colors are not allowed to impact what determines basically the the actual sequence of cars that are moving
on the floor which means they can only do optimization at the last minute they can only sort of say okay now we have to
change the orders of the cars if we want to minimize the number of paint switches
and by changing the orders of the car i mean virtual swaps so they find two cars that are identical on the line and they
basically swap their order if they needed different paints so that they can maximize the sequence of colors of cars
and that are going to receive like a dark base coat versus the set they're going to get a light base coat
and they managed to do this calling the quantum computer and they saw an eighty percent reduction in waste so there was
uh five times fewer color switches which means that um that introduces less cost and also means uh less waste basically
coming from the production line okay the the example here was save on
foods this is a really meaningful example to me because i started talking with the folks at save on foods uh just as the
pandemic was starting and this was a time where they were seeing a lot of volatility in the in the business and
they recognized that you know grocery store like running grocery stores is really important and crucial for all of us and i'm sure many of us who were
thinking about you know am i going to be able to buy the groceries that i need every day um you know that was really important and it's something that they
really took to heart so they were really looking at their own internal operations and saying you know there's a lot of
grocery optimization things that we're doing that take a lot of time and so we work closely with them and we
help them to develop a problem formulation for some of these important problems and that managed to reduce the
complexity of the problem from 25 operational hours down to two minutes
and these were not like the super fun operational hours these were the ground and pound working your way
through grocery optimization hours so the the folks who are actually working on this problem were delighted to
actually see this solution this allowed them to focus on other aspects of their business that they felt were going to be
really important for them and the other thing is that when you have to spend 25 hours doing a task you've got to do it way ahead of time
but if you can do it in two minutes you can start to do it with like much more relevant real-time information so
it was a really big impact for the business and like the volkswagen example they've actually now gone into other areas
looking at their business to determine other places where they can use the quantum computers in application
denso is a large auto parts manufacturer in japan they've also looked at traffic
flow optimization but in particular they were interested in optimizations on their manufacturing
floor so they have a whole series of autonomously vehicles that are moving things around their manufacturing floor
and they're not allowed to collide so if their paths cross one of them has to wait while the other one is passing
through that particular area and it's really important that they don't collide because that's a lot more costly than just trying to save a little
time and so they were actually able to map that problem again you know finding the right problem formulation for it for our
quantum technology and in so doing even maximizing for safety they managed to reduce the wait times by 15
okay so um those are i'm leading right into the application
examples just to kind of really bring us into okay there's several different spaces where we can use this um but
there's also like you know quantum computing it's new it's not like the types of technologies that we're really familiar with uh why are people making
the change it's it's sort of disruptive and the reason is because of the enormous
potential so a lot of the theory in the early days for quantum computers showed that they have the possibility to to
really speed up calculations and what's interesting is so particularly
there's lots of different models of quantum computing and there's also lots of different ways to implement quantum computers at d-wave we're doing this
with solid-state chips so we're actually fabricating them the way that our semiconductor chips are made
and that has actually allowed us to double the size of our processors and increase their level of integration regularly
year on year sort of like every 18 months to two years so we're seeing an exponential growth in the size of the
processors just like you get with intel processors the difference is that the problem complexity is growing
exponentially with its scale so there's this possible opportunity for a super exponential growth and
computational power and any place where you get a super exponential growth you suddenly get this massive disruption where you used to do
everything in a particular way you know and then a short period of time later you it's radically like the wrong
solution for what you're doing we had a story about blockbuster a little bit earlier and what i find is really fun here is
these are a couple of images from work that we've done in quantum material simulation so simulating lattices to
find what their properties their magnetic properties are going to be and that might seem a little bit esoteric but magnetic
properties i mean are actually um an important part of electric engines and important parts of a device that we use
commercially um and also for those of you who have a machine learning background
uh there's sort of a machine learning domain which is about drawing probabilistic samples
these lattices can produce really interesting probability distributions that you can sample from which has
interesting implications in machine learning research but the reason that i'm mentioning this is because
in the space of two product generations we went from not being able to calculate
these material properties to being three million times faster than the best classical software that was being used
to do it um and in fact uh we did this work in collaboration with google
uh and they had actually hired one of the world experts on their quantum program who had done simulations of this
kind and we worked with them in terms of optimizing the classical side uh to compete with so this really was a pretty
heavy sort of benchmarking lift and then you you take that and then you contrast with um some of the things
we're talking about in terms of real world examples like the 500 times speed up and save on foods so it's it's

we're fairly far up the technology stack and the reason i'm saying that is because we developed that technology

through where the problem formulation is here but first i'm going to start you by like the description of the problem and the the situation here is a set where
you have um a series of hospitals which are spread over a city location and some of them may have shortages of beds and
some of them may have surpluses of beds and so what you'd like to do is put them together into groups where
amongst a small group a relatively small partition there's a surplus of bids and then you
want to do that in a way where you're minimizing the transfer costs of having to move resources between them whether it's patients to beds or other resources
so that's basically the challenge and and the idea is to develop a demo which um builds against that
so what's nice about this is that there's a lot in the code this is readable okay good i can zoom it
in a little bit if we want to see it a touch closer there's a lot in the code which is about installing packages and setting up
variables but really the actual key part when you're looking at using quantum computers an application
is about problem formulation what are the elements where you're actually going to formulate the problem that's going to
get passed to the quantum computer or the quantum hybrid solver and these are those elements so the first one is a
constraint each hospital must be assigned to exactly one group so in this case there's a nice helpful
mathematical formulation here some over all binary variables which assign a hospital to a group must
be one and only one so it says sort of here at the beginning we're going to set for each pair of
hospital index i and group there's going to be a binary variable which indicates that that hospital has
been assigned to that group so what we're going to do is say okay well then for every hospital we want to have a one
hot constraint and this is called add discrete because it basically makes like a discrete variable where only one of
the options the discrete variable has is allowed to be on for all the binary variables
in the range of groups the second constraint is now we need to make sure that we have a positive number
of beds so in this case it's just for every hospital that's going to be in that group you're going to have a binary
variable saying you know 0 is going to be multiplying 0 when it's not in the group and 1 is going to be
multiplying by the number of beds and you need to add those all up and make sure that it's greater than zero so
again just for you know g and the number of groups that you have you'd want to add a constraint so that the sum of the
binary variable zero one if the hospital is in the group times the number of beds that it has which might be positive or
negative if it's a surplus for a shortage um is greater than or equal to zero and so um
this hybrid solver that we built is specifically designed to allow you to just construct constraints in like a
very natural language using this you know symbolic greater than or equal to some number um to make it like much faster and
easier to uh sort of write these out whereas let's say in previous demonstrations i would have gone into like truth tables to show you exactly
how these are constructed um and and and you're doing this by thinking through the problem and then
adding a component saying okay well i have this constraint i'm going to add that in i'm going to have this concern i'm going to add that in and cqm here is
the object which represents the model of your problem the last thing is an objective and for this objective we're basically going to
sum over all the distances that where transfers are going to have to take place within your group so this is a few
more lines in this case we're going to take we're going to set an objective which is equal to zero so if you're trying to minimize
an objective you're trying to get the number as low as you can as negative as it can be so if you start with zero that's a constant there's no opportunity
to optimize and then we're going to pick a hospital and a bed out of the set and then a second hospital in a bed out of the set
and then basically just restrict ourselves to the set where the first one has a surplus and the second one has a shortage as
we're iterating over all the possible ones there and then say okay for these two
we want to add to the objective the distance for the transfer between the hospital with a surplus and a shortage
you don't need to keep track of all the distances only transfers that would take place between hospitals that have um
positive and then negative distances so you add all those distances and if you exclude the hospitals from
the group then those distances don't get factored in those binary variables will be zero and they'll zero out those terms
and after those distances are added in then that that sets your objective you set your objective for your cqm and now
you've just constructed a model um this might feel a little unsatisfying
for those of you who are algorithm designers but that is an important part of knowing
programming quantum computers is that you're not telling it how to step through the problem you're not having to tell it how to use superposition and
tunneling to solve the problem you're actually just describing the problem it's a little bit like cutting the
sudoku out of the newspaper and then passing it to the machine and coming back with the numbers filled in um so
so that's it the rest of the program is the rest of the handling this is the section that deals with formulating that

that formulation that i just described to you that's all that's basically in the code for running it and then i'm going to give it a minimum
